content.prompt: Two long, parallel, current-carrying wires are located near each other. The wires have currents I and 2I and are a distance ℓ apart. Which of the following claims, with the appropriate evidence, is correct about the position around the wires where the magnetic field is zero?

choices.label: The magnetic field is zero at a horizontal distance that is halfway between the wires, because the position is equidistant from each wire.
The magnetic field is zero at a horizontal distance ℓ3 from the wire that has current 2I and in between both wires, because the position should be closer to the wire that has the greatest current.
The magnetic field is zero at a horizontal distance ℓ3 from the wire that has current I and in between both wires, because the position should be closer to the wire that has the smallest current.
The magnetic field is zero at a horizontal distance ℓ4 from the wire that has current I and in between both wires, because the position should be closer to the wire that has the smallest current.
There is no point between the wires where the magnetic field is zero, because the currents in each wire travel in the same direction.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
